title: The most important century in human history

options.label: B
options.text: The invention of the atomic bomb

options.label: C
options.text: The emergence of a new major religion

options.label: D
options.text: The Industrial Revolution

options.label: A
options.text: Artificial narrow intelligence

options.label: B
options.text: Artificial general intelligence

options.label: C
options.text: The Industrial Revolution

options.label: D
options.text: The invention of the atomic bomb

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what could be a potential outcome if artificial general intelligence emerges with deep respect for human life and a desire to solve humanity's troubles?

options.label: A
options.text: It could lead to the extinction of humanity

options.label: B
options.text: It could lock humanity into one ideology that would be resistant to change

options.label: C
options.text: It could make humanity's troubles worse

options.label: D
options.text: It could have no impact on humanity's future

options.label: A
options.text: It's a technical challenge that requires a lot of coding

options.label: B
options.text: It's a philosophical challenge that requires a lot of delicate and thoughtful work

options.label: C
options.text: It's a financial challenge that requires a lot of funding

options.label: D
options.text: It's a historical challenge that requires a lot of research

title: When you're an ant but also a fungus tycoon - Charles Wallace

multiple-choice.question: What is the unique relationship between leafcutter ants and fungus?

options.label: A
options.text: The ants prey on the fungus for food.

options.label: B
options.text: The ants use the fungus as a shelter.

options.label: C
options.text: The ants domesticated the fungus, which provides essential nutrients.

options.label: D
options.text: The ants and fungus have a neutral relationship.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the queen leafcutter ant in the colony?

options.label: A
options.text: She is responsible for foraging for food.

options.label: B
options.text: She lays thousands of eggs every day and is tended to by members of her entourage.

options.label: C
options.text: She is in charge of defending the colony from predators.

options.label: D
options.text: She is responsible for maintaining the fungal gardens.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the leafcutter ants' trails?

options.label: A
options.text: To mark their territory.

options.label: B
options.text: To communicate with other ants.

options.label: C
options.text: To create efficient highways for foraging.

options.label: D
options.text: To store food.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the tiny cockroaches in the leafcutter ant colony?

options.label: A
options.text: They are predators of the ants.

options.label: B
options.text: They are prey for the ants.

options.label: C
options.text: They feed opportunistically off the fungus and hitch rides on soon-to-be queens.

options.label: D
options.text: They are parasites of the ants.

multiple-choice.question: What is the threat to the leafcutter ant colony and cockroach relationship with the fungus?

options.label: A
options.text: A rival species of ants.

options.label: B
options.text: A disease that affects the ants.

options.label: C
options.text: A parasitic micro-fungus called Escovopsis.

options.label: D
options.text: A lack of food.

title: The man who lost his sense of touch - Antonio Cataldo

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition that Ian Waterman was diagnosed with after collapsing from a severe case of what seemed to be gastric flu?

options.label: A
options.text: Deafferentation

options.label: B
options.text: Somatosensory disorder

options.label: C
options.text: Nerve damage

options.label: D
options.text: Muscle weakness

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the system that oversees all the sensations arising from the surface and interior of our bodies?

options.label: A
options.text: Somatosensory system

options.label: B
options.text: Nervous system

options.label: C
options.text: Muscular system

options.label: D
options.text: Circulatory system

multiple-choice.question: What type of receptors sense mechanical deformation of the skin, which could be triggered by low or high frequency vibrations, a stretch, or simply light, static pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: Thermoreceptors

options.label: B
options.text: Mechanoreceptors

options.label: C
options.text: Nociceptors

options.label: D
options.text: Propriocepters

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the condition that can be caused by being deprived of social touch, characterized by anxiety, depression, high blood pressure, and even a weakened immune system?

options.label: A
options.text: Touch starvation

options.label: B
options.text: Somatosensory disorder

options.label: C
options.text: Deafferentation

options.label: D
options.text: Nerve damage

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of damage to the somatosensory system, which can manifest in a wide variety of ways, including loss of tactile sensations, difficulty gauging strength, and deprivation of social touch?

options.label: A
options.text: Muscle weakness

options.label: B
options.text: Nerve damage

options.label: C
options.text: Somatosensory disorder

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: How do airplanes actually fly? - Raymond Adkins

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why airplanes need an upward force, called lift, to stay aloft?

options.label: A
options.text: Because air is a solid medium that resists movement.

options.label: B
options.text: Because things that are heavier than air require an upward force to stay aloft.

options.label: C
options.text: Because air is a fluid medium that provides lift to objects.

options.label: D
options.text: Because airplanes are made of heavy materials that require lift.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main reasons why Einstein's airplane wing design was flawed?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was too curved and steeply angled.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was based on an incomplete theory of flight.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was too flat and didn't provide enough lift.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was designed for a different type of aircraft.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the correct explanation for how lift is generated in an airplane wing?

options.label: A
options.text: Air molecules traveling over the top of a curved wing cover a longer distance than those traveling underneath.

options.label: B
options.text: Air molecules floating above and below the wing don't need to meet back up, and the air above reaches the wing's trailing edge much faster than the air beneath.

options.label: C
options.text: Air flowing across the lower surface of the wing experiences more speed than the air above, creating a higher pressure difference.

options.label: D
options.text: The wing's curvature is the cause of lift, and a flat wing can't create lift.

multiple-choice.question: What is not a factor that influences lift, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The air that's flowing meters beyond the wing's surface

options.label: B
options.text: The air that's swept up, then down

options.label: C
options.text: Air vortices formed at the wing's tips

options.label: D
options.text: The pressure difference between the upper and lower surfaces of the wing

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the set of formulas used by engineers to precisely model air's flow around a wing and detail how lift is generated?

options.label: A
options.text: The Bernoulli's Principle

options.label: B
options.text: The Navier-Stokes equations

options.label: C
options.text: The Euler's Method

options.label: D
options.text: The lift equation

title: History vs. Thomas Jefferson - Frank Cogliano

multiple-choice.question: What was Thomas Jefferson's role in the fight for freedom and equality in America?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a leader in the abolitionist movement.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a key figure in the American Revolution.

options.label: C
options.text: He was part of America's fight for freedom and equality.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a prominent figure in the Civil Rights Movement.

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the main issues with Thomas Jefferson's actions regarding slavery?

options.label: A
options.text: He did not have enough power to change the institution of slavery.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a strong advocate for the abolition of slavery.

options.label: C
options.text: He held over 600 people in slavery despite condemning it.

options.label: D
options.text: He only owned a few slaves.

multiple-choice.question: What was one of Thomas Jefferson's significant contributions to religious freedom?

options.label: A
options.text: He supported the separation of church and state.

options.label: B
options.text: He advocated for the establishment of a national church.

options.label: C
options.text: He led the charge for the creation of a new national religion.

options.label: D
options.text: He supported the persecution of minority religions.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Thomas Jefferson's relationship with Sally Hemings?

options.label: A
options.text: He freed all of the enslaved people on his plantation.

options.label: B
options.text: He ended his relationship with Hemings and freed her family.

options.label: C
options.text: He fathered six children with Hemings and kept the relationship secret.

options.label: D
options.text: He sold Hemings to another plantation owner.

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the reasons why Thomas Jefferson's legacy is problematic?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a strong advocate for the abolition of slavery.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a key figure in the American Revolution.

options.label: C
options.text: He failed to uphold his own ideals regarding equality and slavery.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a prominent figure in the Civil Rights Movement.

title: You don't actually know what your future self wants - Shankar Vendantam

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon that Shankar refers to as the "illusion of continuity"?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that our past selves are completely different from our present selves.

options.label: B
options.text: The tendency to imagine that we will remain the same people in the future.

options.label: C
options.text: The concept that our cells and organs are constantly being replaced.

options.label: D
options.text: The notion that our personalities and preferences are fixed.

multiple-choice.question: According to Shankar, what happens to our cells and bodies over time, making us a "different person"?

options.label: A
options.text: They remain the same, with no changes or replacements.

options.label: B
options.text: They are constantly being replaced, but the organization and structure remain the same.

options.label: C
options.text: They are constantly being replaced, and the organization and structure also change.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not replaced, but our perception of them changes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "ship of Theseus" thought experiment, and what does it relate to?

options.label: A
options.text: A ship that is constantly being repaired and replaced, but remains the same.

options.label: B
options.text: A ship that is being replaced with a new one, but the original ship remains the same.

options.label: C
options.text: A thought experiment that asks whether a ship remains the same if all its parts are replaced over time.

options.label: D
options.text: A ship that is being used to explore the concept of personal identity.

multiple-choice.question: What is Shankar's advice on how to deal with the problem of our future selves being different from present selves?

options.label: A
options.text: To ignore the problem and assume that our future selves will be the same.

options.label: B
options.text: To accept the idea that we will be different people in the future and take an active role in shaping who we will become.

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on our present selves and not worry about our future selves.

options.label: D
options.text: To try to freeze our present selves in time and prevent any changes from occurring.

multiple-choice.question: What is the third piece of advice that Shankar gives on how to deal with the problem of future selves being different from present selves?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on our strengths and weaknesses and try to become a better version of ourselves.

options.label: B
options.text: To be brave and take risks, knowing that our future selves will have different capacities and strengths.

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore our future selves and focus on our present selves.

options.label: D
options.text: To try to prevent any changes from occurring and remain the same person.

title: Is it possible to lose weight fast? - Hei Man Chan

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the diet in which dieters swallow an unhatched tapeworm and let it grow inside them by consuming undigested meals?

options.label: A
options.text: Tapeworm diet

options.label: B
options.text: Extreme calorie reduction diet

options.label: C
options.text: Detoxification diet

options.label: D
options.text: Juice diet

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between Sam's and Felix's diet plans?

options.label: A
options.text: Sam's plan is to eat almost nothing, while Felix's plan is to gradually decrease his calorie intake.

options.label: B
options.text: Sam's plan is to gradually decrease his calorie intake, while Felix's plan is to dramatically cut his calorie intake.

options.label: C
options.text: Sam's plan is to eat only healthy meals, while Felix's plan is to eat almost nothing.

options.label: D
options.text: Sam's plan is to exercise regularly, while Felix's plan is to exercise rarely.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to Felix's body when he drastically cuts his calorie intake?

options.label: A
options.text: His body starts breaking down his emergency glucose supply, stored in the liver in the form of glycogen.

options.label: B
options.text: His body starts breaking down his entire store of emergency glucose in just 18 hours.

options.label: C
options.text: His body starts breaking down his muscles.

options.label: D
options.text: His body starts burning fat cells as a major energy source.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with extreme calorie reduction diets?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too specific and can be used as general cure-alls.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too restrictive and can lead to malnutrition.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a shock to the system and can have negative side effects.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too expensive and can be difficult to follow.

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended approach to weight loss according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Trying to lose weight fast through extreme diets.

options.label: B
options.text: Gradually decreasing calorie intake and increasing regular exercise.

options.label: C
options.text: Cutting out certain food groups to provide specific nutrients.

options.label: D
options.text: Sticking to a juice diet for multiple weeks.

title: The myth of Zeus' test - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What did the two mysterious, shrouded figures ask for when they knocked on every door in the hillside village?

options.label: A
options.text: They asked for money and gold.

options.label: B
options.text: They asked for food and shelter.

options.label: C
options.text: They asked for a place to rest and a hot bath.

options.label: D
options.text: They asked for a tour of the village.

multiple-choice.question: What did Baucis and Philemon do to prepare for their guests, despite their limited resources?

options.label: A
options.text: They bought new furniture and decorations.

options.label: B
options.text: They cooked a simple meal and offered their visitors hot baths.

options.label: C
options.text: They went on a shopping spree and prepared a lavish feast.

options.label: D
options.text: They ignored their guests and went to bed.

multiple-choice.question: What did the gods reveal to Baucis and Philemon after they had shown true xenia to their guests?

options.label: A
options.text: They were actually demons in disguise.

options.label: B
options.text: They were the spirits of their ancestors.

options.label: C
options.text: They were Zeus and Hermes, the ruler of the gods and his son.

options.label: D
options.text: They were the guardians of the village.

multiple-choice.question: What was the punishment that Zeus and Hermes inflicted on the townspeople for refusing to shelter the gods?

options.label: A
options.text: They turned them into animals.

options.label: B
options.text: They cast them underwater, leaving only Baucis and Philemon's home intact.

options.label: C
options.text: They turned them into statues.

options.label: D
options.text: They made them invisible.

multiple-choice.question: What did Philemon request from the gods when they asked if there was anything they desired?

options.label: A
options.text: He asked to be made rich and famous.

options.label: B
options.text: He asked to be granted eternal youth.

options.label: C
options.text: He asked to be permitted to care for the new temple and to die together with Baucis.

options.label: D
options.text: He asked to be given the power to heal any disease.

title: The original ring of power - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: According to the legend of the Ring of Gyges, what supernatural ability does the ring possess?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to grant immense wealth

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to make the wearer invisible

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to grant eternal youth

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to speak any language

options.text: That justice is the most important virtue

options.label: B
options.text: That people act justly because it's what's right

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: Reason, spirit, and appetite

options.label: B
options.text: Reason, emotion, and will

options.label: C
options.text: Reason, passion, and intellect

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between Glaucon's and Socrates' views on justice?

options.label: A
options.text: Glaucon believes that justice is a burden, while Socrates believes it's a reward

options.label: B
options.text: Glaucon believes that justice is a virtue, while Socrates believes it's a vice

options.label: C
options.text: Glaucon believes that justice is imposed by authority, while Socrates believes it's a natural obligation

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the significance of the Ring of Gyges in the context of Western philosophy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a symbol of ultimate power and wealth

options.label: B
options.text: It is a symbol of the corrupting influence of power

options.label: C
options.text: It is a symbol of the importance of external influences in shaping human behavior

options.label: D
options.text: It is a symbol of the tension between reason and appetite
